ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A lot better understanding of microeconomic fundamentals as well as general math techniques and proof intuition.
I learned the fundamentals of micro theory and GE.
Good practice applying the proof-based skills learned in real analysis followed by an interesting application of multivariable calculus.

This course was comprehensive and I learnt a lot from it. However, it may not be the best Econ course to start with for students who do not come from a prior Econ majors background. However, as a student taking a masters level Econ course for the first time, I learnt a lot of new concepts that will have a lot of use in my future research.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course was extremely well organized. The two halves were really well paired. Problem sets were carefully thought-out to reinforce the material, and the lecture notes (first half) and textbook (second half) were excellent resources that perfectly matched the lectures.
The first half is too fast. The second half needs more explanations for big picture I think.

The second half seemed to be glorified calculus/algebra, which I suppose is good to go through, but I'm not convinced it made me that much better as an economist. The first half was very challenging but very interesting.
Strength -- well-organized lecture notes and homeworks

This course has a good curriculum, nice review material and good professors and TAs. However, it is not the best introductory course in Microeconomics. Sometimes it is so mathematical that we fail to see the economic insights in it.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, essential for anyone trying to develop an economics skillset. Prerequisites should be considered for those with weak math background.
Yes, essential for anyone pursuing studies in economics.
Yes and No. Taking Mira's course is recommended, but I don't think it is worth taking Truman's course because his lecture is terrible.

I would definitely recommend it to all quant PHD students but I wish there was a more basic course before this for students not from Econ backgrounds who wish to work in quantitative fields like Accounting or Quant Marketing.
